title: LAPD recruitment ad on Breitbart was so bewildering that the chief wondered if it was a fake
text:
The site became infamous for its shock stories, including several targeting gays and Jews. One story championed the Confederate flag two weeks after a white supremacist murdered nine black parishioners in a Charleston church in 2015.

The advertisement, noted first by Daily Beast Editor in Chief Noah Shachtman, triggered a social-media backlash. Seeking to distance itself from Breitbart entirely, the department said the advertisement was “a negative juxtaposition to our core values.”

AD

AD

“The LAPD celebrates diversity and embraces it within our ranks, and within the city we serve,” the department said Saturday. The LAPD also said it has opened an inquiry into how the ad landed on the Breitbart page in the first place.

The discovery was so bewildering to the department that Chief Michel Moore said on Twitter that the LAPD wondered whether the ad was a “spoof” or an effort to discredit the department by linking it to the far-right operation.

“No. LAPD did NOT purchase or otherwise acquire ad space on that website. Senior leadership at ads City Personnel Department also relayed they did not authorize or pay for this ad either,” Moore said on Twitter.

AD

It is unclear how long the ad has appeared on the site and whether there is more than one such ad.

By Saturday evening, the department discovered the source of the advertisement’s path to Breitbart: The agency purchases advertising through Google, which typically places ads on websites using demographic information rather than deliberately targeting certain publications.

AD

“We have stopped these Google Ads altogether while we reexamine our ad filters and take all necessary steps to ensure tighter control of ad settings,” the department said.

Ad buyers may have been able to avoid the issue by filtering out specific websites beforehand, NBC News noted.

AD

Breitbart did not respond to a request for comment. In a statement to the Los Angeles Times, spokeswoman Elizabeth Moore said Breitbart is “one of the most pro-police, pro-law-enforcement news organizations in America,” claimed its newsroom is diverse and said the site knows it has “strong readership among the rank-and-file in the LAPD.”

The site is known for antagonizing minorities and often defending the Trump administration on familiar themes — “anti-immigration, pro-economic nationalism [and] skepticism of multiculturalism,” The Washington Post’s Paul Farhi wrote.

AD

In recent years, Breitbart appears to have sought a more straightforward news approach. But some of its most shocking headlines haunt the publication, such as “The Smartest People in the World Are All Men,” “Birth Control Makes Women Unattractive and Crazy,” “Bill Kristol: Republican spoiler, renegade Jew” and “Data: Young Muslims Are a Ticking Time Bomb in the West.”

Advertisers have steered clear in recent years, Farhi wrote, and a glut of far-right news websites have further lured readers from Breitbart.
